Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Highly-Efficient Dynamic Prediction Models for Quality Improvement in Cold Rolling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award supports fundamental research to lay the foundation to significantly improve the quality of aluminum, steel, copper, and brass sheets manufactured on cold rolling mills. These metal sheets are important raw materials for many products, including aircraft, automobiles, ships, refrigerators, computers, electric motors, and buildings. Rolled metal sheets of poor geometric quality need to undergo costly additional processing. Results from this research will lead to new mill control strategies that improve rolling quality and productivity for these metal sheets in important emerging markets. The research will benefit the economic competitiveness and security of the United States. The direct involvement of engineering students from the under-represented groups (including women and persons with autism) in manufacturing will provide positive benefits to education and society.

Geometry defects in cold rolling of thin aluminum, steel, copper, and brass sheets arise from the mismatch of incoming strip thickness profiles with mill roll-bite profiles. Detailed roll-bite behavior stems from complex transient effects of mill structural deflection, thermal expansion, roll grinding, and roll wear, and is difficult to predict. The highly-efficient dynamic models to be created in this work will integrate structural, thermal, and wear patterns using a novel, mixed finite element approach to determine three-dimensional, high-frequency nonlinear dynamic responses of rolling mills. The models will allow for more efficient and accurate multi degree-of-freedom prediction of mill dynamics than is possible with single degree-of-freedom or full-scale finite element models. The efficient nonlinear, multi degree-of-freedom dynamic models will also be combined with Bayesian/Markov-Chain Monte-Carlo control approaches, to yield a better understanding of mill behavior in spite of significant random process variations. The understanding gained may lead to new on-mill roll grinding methods to correct geometry defects, novel two-dimensional (instead of centerline-only) gauge control, and probabilistic approaches to improve geometric quality of rolled metals.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project has led to fundamental research that can be used to improve the geometric quality of aluminum, steel, copper, and brass raw materials manufactured in sheet form on cold rolling mills. These rolled sheet materials represent the foundational components of economically important products in several major industries; including those that manufacture aircraft, automobiles, ships, refrigerators, computers, electric motors, and buildings. The findings from the research have resulted in new information and computer simulation models that can help reduce costly additional processing for thin metal sheets that suffer from poor geometric quality during fabrication by the rolling process. The research findings also help meet the increasing demand for both high-strength and lightweight products made from metal alloys, which in turn leads to benefits in market competitiveness, energy efficiency, and national security capability. A key technical outcome of the research is a new, highly-efficient computational method that can predict the occurrence of high-frequency flatness defects in the rolled metal sheet that arise due to subtle disturbances in the rolling process. The new simulation technology can be adopted by manufacturers for implementation into rolling mill control systems to help correct for such defects. This will be particularly beneficial in the high value economic markets driven by ultra-thin gauge rolled sheet metal products. The software developed has also been made freely available for companies and educational institutions to adopt for research, engineering, and manufacturing purposes. Aside from the technical accomplishments, the project has generated important educational and societal outcomes by allowing engineering students and young adults with autism to learn how to work effectively together on teams consisting of both neurotypical and non-neurotypical members. Videos of the annual “Engineering Brighter Futures for Autism” events have been made publicly available on YouTube to help increase public awareness and lead to better workforce recruiting and training.


Last Modified: 07/21/2021
Modified by: Arif S Malik
